author: vaigyanik

description.text:
A pair of cutters to make my take on the Jammie Dodger!  
Recently I had my blackberry bush finally give edible fruit, so much infact I decided to make some jam. I have never made jam before and my first batch was rather... thick. It wasn't any use for spreading on toast, but I did notice that it is a similar consistancy to the jam used in Jammie Dodgers. So with a shortbread recipe I made my own with these cutters.

Recipe for Shortbread: 175g Butter
75g Caster Sugar
250g Plain Flour Cream the butter with the caster sugar, then follow with the plain flour. Work together into a ball, wrap dough in food wrap and place in fridge for 30 mins or freezer for 10-15. Flour your work surface and then take out dough and roll to approx 5-6mm thick. Dip the end of each cutter in flour before cutting out the shapes, make sure you have the same number of tops and bottoms! The tops will need to have the middle bit removed before placing them onto a baking sheet and into the oven at 150C for 25 minutes. Once cooked take out the oven and transfer to a cooling rack. Allow to cool. When they are cold take the bottom piece and turn it so the flat side is facing up and put some jam on it, spreading it out. Then place a top piece on the jam. If you have jam (like me) that is too firm then heat it briefly in a microwave to soften it before putting on biscuit. Shop brought will work just as well :)

comments.text: Love them! Perfect size and beveled edges are the best design of all the cookie cutters I’ve printed! Thank you for helping me make a great gift for a friend!  (I used a different recipe and made spicy versions with micks spicy jam and rasberry jam as per a request)

description.text:
For some inexplicable reason, there about 1000 different variants of these common quick release buckles. I need some male ones to mate up with the female ones on my Hydra 4.5, so I spent a stupid amount of time refining this model, but it's pretty good now. The male buckle is quite close to the OEM part and holds up quite well in ABS (haven't tried PLA).

There are a couple extras from my project in there but they're a bit more of a work in progress. The male and female keyholes on these will mate up those found on many pieces of Leatt gear.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select 3D Printer

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.06

Infill:

100%

Notes:

The buckle itself should be printed flat on the bed.

The cover if you use it should be printed upright, with the cap of the pin perpendicular to the bed, for maximal strength, though I still didn't find it to be strong enough for my application.

The pivot guide should be printed flat, though you might change this for your application, depending on what direction your expecting pull in. This part could probably be redesigned to be stronger.

description.text: customized with 3D Slash!

This enclosure accommodates a common AC to 5v (5A & 8A) PSU from ebay/aliexpress, and a Raspberry Pi 2 and Raspberry Pi Model B+ (probably Pi3 too, but not tested yet).
http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/191733870857 - 5v 5a/8a - 110mm78mm35mm

The Pi is my HTPC running OSMC and my intention was to provide enough amps to run ambilight/hyperion/boblight LEDs and keep cable mess to a minimum by integrating the power and pi into one box.

The area above the Pi provides space for a prototype circuit - Arduino Nano, Pro Mini, or a logic lever shifter like I've done.

Still to do:

  • Design mounting system (VESA possibly).

UPDATE:
V4:

  • Airflow slots at the PSU end and in the proto area.
  • Dowel ridge around the sides of the case for better alignment of the 2 halves when screwed together and for strength (very loose tolerance at the moment).
  • Re-designed bottom vent holes.
  • Mesh now as tidy as I'll get it.
  • PSU moved 1mm closer to the side to give more room for cables on the other side.

UPDATE:
V3:

  • Tidied mesh some more.
  • Fixed the ethernet & usb ports area so it fits the Pi nice.
  • Added hole by the USB ports for running wires out of the case.
  • Changed the fan hole, to accept any fan between 30mm and 60mm. Note: if using one of the smaller fans, there will be large holes around it.
  • enlarged the holes around the USB power, HDMI and 3.5mm jack ports.

UPDATE:
V2:

  • Added 4th screw hole.
  • Pi has been moved 6mm up to make space for 4th screw hole.
  • Enlarged screw holes for larger head screws (9mm head will fit)
  • Mesh is a little more tidy, more dimensional accuracy.

Printer:

Creatornator

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

More = stronger

Notes:

I'm using a 0.8mm nozzle, so you'll need to compensate your setup accordingly.

I printed this on a raft with 3 top/bottom layers, 3 loops and 30% infill.

Came out very strong.
It can be printed with fewer loops and more infill.
Everything is designed to have at least 1 loop at 0.8mm nozzle width.

title: Parametric Cap / Plug with Optional Tether

description.text:
Started out as a remix of someone's work, but so changed now as to irrelevant. Name says it all. I've only printed it in TPU, for which it works great, though I'm sure it would be ok in other materials too.

Attached STLs for a few variants based off of this:

  • A Hi-Lift Jack Handle Cap, which has a couple retainer "nubs" added. Designed around the Baja Buster handle actually. That way when it smacks you in the face, it hurts less...
  • Jack Shaft Cap is for the handle of my floor jack. Also mostly so when I smack my face on it, it hurts less. Recommend about a 15% infill for this and the above, in TPU of course, for the requisite softness.
  • Also included caps for my GreenWorks Pressure washer. The genius of these is, since they are sized around the mating dimensions of the hose and the pressure washer itself, the caps can be connected to keep them clean while the pressure washer is in use.

Designed this around LUVSOME cat food cans since we were only feeding half of one at a time to our porch cat. Should work as is for a number of other brands I suspect, and since it's parametric, it can easily be customized if not. As currently configured in the SCAD file and in the last STL file, it seals by the angled surface making contact with the lip, which makes it easier to remove, while the 0.4 version seals to the can body, with a negative clearance, so seals more tightly, but is much more difficult to put on/off.

I guess this means the midpoint isn't set perfect in Simplify3D... it sounds like it just barely hits the limit moving to the left... and the "blob" S3D makes at the start interferes with the rest of the print...

Simplify3D does not like the size of it... so I made a 90% version... and then a 85% version so it will fit more likely... will be trying to print all of them starting with the smallest.

Expect updates soon... if not... post a comment and ask :)

description.text: The Cleveland Indians Logo, now put into files that you can 3D print yourself to have your own Chief Wahoo! All it takes is a couple dual extrusion prints and a little assembly. Still working on making the pieces fit nicer, so I'll be updating the files as time goes on. The files are all too large because i forgot to scale when i first drew it up, but I'll be uploading corrected files as soon as I can. Below are the instructions on how to dual extrude the different pieces so that you can put them together the same way I did.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2X

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.2 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Infill:
The infill isn't really a big deal, because the print isn't thick enough. You just need enough infill for it to keep the top from messing up, and less will speed up the print.

How to Print:
Note - obviously, since this has many dual extruding parts, you're going to need a dual-extruding printer to do this. It would be possible to do on a normal printer one piece at a time, there is just going to be a bunch of assembly, and it probably wouldn't turn out as nice. But hey, if you're up for the challenge, the files are here! Anywho, back to explaining how to print.

This print was sort of tricky, because there are 3 different colors, which obviously doesn't work with a printer that can only do 2 at a time. So to get around this, I did 2 separate dual extruded prints, one red-black, and one white-black, then assembled them. If you are using a Makerbot Replicator 2X, you're in luck. I've included the setup files that can be directly imported into the Makerbot program to be dual extruded, you just have to be familiar with how to set up a dual extrusion thing. If that's you, use those, and once printed, you can skip to the post-printing section!

For the rest of you, I will try to make it easier for you as soon as I can, but for right now, I've uploaded the files, both CAD and stl, all of which are far to large to print, because I forgot to scale down the photo first. Oops. :P But I will fix that problem as soon as I can. If you feel like taking the time to scale all the stl's in the program so they fit like I did, go for it! That's why I included the files. If you want to, I'll explain next what to do.

This will be a rough explanation, I'll clean it up once I have the corrected files.
Import Chief Wahoo Face Black STL and Chief Wahoo Face Red STL into the program connected to your printer. You'll have to scale them until the two pieces are lined up correctly. Really, just get them as close as possible, doesn't have to be perfect. Then, set the pieces to dual extrude the right colors, however your program does that. Then, do the same with the mouth pieces, the eyes, and then the headband just prints in white by itself.

I'll try and add some more pictures to help see how to print it, maybe even a video. This is my first published thing, so I hope you all can understand my instructions enough to make it work!

After you've successfully printed all the pieces, it should be pretty easy to see how the pieces fit together. Right now, the pieces aren't a perfect fit, so you'll have to do some sanding to make them fit nicely. Once I did that, I put glue on on the back to ensure all the pieces stayed in place. This kept the front clean and looking nice. Just make sure you know which way Chief Wahoo faces so you don't put all the glue on the wrong side. That'd be bad.

And that's it! Hope you all are able to use this to make your own Chief Wahoo to that you can proudly display.

A bipedal robotic chicken. It stands about 7 inches tall; parts are easy to assemble. The wings are connected with a paperclip trimmed to the right length and made permanent with a drop of hot glue on either end. The head is attached with a spring of appropriate size and hot glue. The servos are hot glued underneath body, and legs are then screwed on to servo horns. The hot glue works great, servos stay put and have never moved or fallen off. Make the body, head, and wings as light as possible, but make the legs more dense for stability. I did 10% infill, and 75% for the legs, respectively. Traction for feet is necessary so that it moves forward, you can roughen the feet (sand them), or apply a thin layer of hot glue. There will likely be some trial and error with finding the right amount of traction, but otherwise an easy build.

Components:
Arduino Nano
2 TowerPro SG-92R Mini Servos
2 LED
2 560 Resistor
2 Switch
1 3.7V 240mAh 20C Lipo Battery
http://www.ebay.com/itm/191832481644
1 5V Micro USB 1A 18650 Lithium Battery Charging Board Charger Module
http://www.ebay.com/itm/182244346764

Notes:
I soldered extra wires to Nano, that don't go anywhere, for the purpose of making it look like plumage.
I added some of my code to help others get started. The code works with my build, but will not work with all builds. The traction issue will have to be adjusted in the code based on your own conditions. Surface friction and traction matter quite a bit with a bipedal design.

description.text:
Designed this to fix the squeaking once and for all. The original bearings look like SMF85ZZ and are extremely thin, resulting in tiny balls that just can't take the load (8 Kgf rating?). Flanged 624 bearings much larger, and have room for larger balls resulting in a rating of 49 Kgf. I get them from eBay for about $1 each, and for this build you do need the flange version to keep the belt in line.

Source at https://cad.onshape.com/documents/ad4e3fb2856fd383e6ff196c/w/3b02a236f7d492db0c497771/e/b47ca3f951fe1b9e30adf1b4

The ID is sized for a 4mm bolt to fit without reaming (only tested with PLA on two different printers). Feedback please on the hole size. Why did I move to an outside clamping design, you may ask. It's because I wanted to move the idler up mostly (belts in line are kind of my thing), and didn't want to deal with potential depth differences in the engraved pocket from machine to machine.

BOM

3x top part
3x bottom part
4x M4x45 (yes, an extra)
3x M4 nylock nut
6x M4 washer
6x F624 bearings

Instructions

You can see the stack in the image above, but this area isn't very accessible, so here are instructions to do it easiest (written primarily for Y; for X you need to do steps 3-7 from the top which is more difficult, and loosen something in order to get the bottom piece inserted).

  1. Untension your motor
  2. Remove your existing idler. For both X and Y remove the top laser cut part.

  3. Insert screw through the bottom (taller) bushing, and insert into the hole. Should be reasonably snug.

    (It should look like the photo below)

  4. Add a washer, and the first bearing with the flange down.
  5. Put belt around the bearing.
  6. Add another bearing, flange up, and another washer.

  7. Add top laser cut piece, then push bushing in from the top around the screw.

    (You could add a nut now and be done, but there's an extra step to get it pretty like the cover photo.)

  8. Use another M4 screw (that's why there are 4 on the BOM) to push out the first one through the whole stack. This puts the head on the top, which is easier to find with a hex key, and IMO looks nicer because there are other cap screws already on that face.
  9. Remember to screw down the lasercut part. If there's much of a gap between bearings, feel free to rewind and add a 3rd washer in step 6. If the printed parts don't want to sit flush, sand/file the lower one's small end.
  10. Realign motor pulley and tension. The idler location is a little bit higher (on purpose) to more closely match the carriage attachment point. For the Y one near the endstop, I ended up using a spacer and a longer M5.
Assembly between steps 3 and 4 for Y axis.

description.text:
Based on http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:439657

I needed to charge 6x 18650 cells at a time using my iMax B6.
As I am new to 3d-printing and have no experience using Sketch-up I recreated the design in Tinkercad with 6 slots and some helper-items. Those are not in the .stl file, only the actual case is.

Springs were harvested from old single-cell holders. Bolts, nuts, washers and cableshoes are size M4.

EDIT 06/07-2017

As requested I have redone the model in Fusion 360 based on this video: https://youtu.be/Zn1pGBm67wo regarding dynamic design.
I have uploaded sizes 1-12 cells. The dimensions are as follows:
Size 1 cell: 88 x 27,5 mm
Size 2 cells: 88 x 51 mm
Size 3 cells: 88 x (just keep adding 23,5 mm for the rest of the sizes)...

If you need larger sizes or you have a small printbed, just print two versions and glue them together afterwards.

For some reason Fusion 360 insist on exporting the box on its side, so sorry about the previews. Just lay them flat in your slicer.

“Z” Axis upgrade for Tevo / Tarantula, I had problem with Z Banding & as it was all at the same points in my prints I designed this “Z” axis Upgrade.

The weight of the “X” carriage now sits on a bearing above the standard coupler, There is a washer between the Coupler & the Bearing, The centre of the “Z” rod or plate is around 100mm from the right hand side edge to balance out the weight of the stepper motors.
You will need a 1 x 608zz bearing ( 8mmx22mmx7m).

Printed at 0.2mm Layer, No Support, 50% fill,

Note: Bolt only to the rear of the 2040 profile, Do not use the bolt holes on the underside.

Notes:

SUPPORTS:
Model was designed to be printed without the supports. Top cap part may be printed with the supports, or without it if you do not have problems with the bridges.

Solid version on the Angry Sheep model should be printed WITH the supports.

TOLERANCE:
Please, check you printer settings and calibrate it with tolerance tests, like this http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:34038 . Cap has element, that should be pushed in it, and it will hold tight on good calibrated printers, but may not fit or will be loose on others.

Anyway, that should not be big problem, as you can reduce element size a little or use glue to fix it on the cap.

And don't forget to PAINT THE ANGRY SHEEP! :-D

description.text:
In spite of the fact that they're stoooopid expensive, I decided to use Hue Lightstrips (2nd generation) in my LED Bridge Lamp, so I modified a few parts from Opossums' stellar design to facilitate that. Here's what's included:

  • light_guide_AB-hue
    The two-part (A and B) light guide, modified to support a single LED strip up to ~15mm in width. Hue lightstrips are ~14.5mm wide.
  • light_guide_straight-hue
    The single piece light guide used for the [optional] bridge straight sections. Same modification as above.
  • assembly_jig-hue
    The handy assembly jig modified to accommodate the light guide changes above. I also gave it a flat edge so the sections will easily remain upright while glue dries (see photo) - this simplified the assembly process for me.

Thought it might be useful to share these for anyone else who plans to use Hue Lightstrips (or any other single LED strip less than ~15mm wide) in their LED Bridge Lamp.

UPDATE: You can see the details of my make of the bridge lamp here: http://www.thingiverse.com/make:275750

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Use the same resolution settings you use for the rest of the bridge parts and you should be fine. These particular parts require no supports or rafts.

I've printed these parts on both a Taz 6 and an Original Prusa i3 MK2 with great results.

title: Short Feather Board
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Not a true remix, but not original either. I needed a shorter board for a vertical hold down. The full size one in the original thing stuck up too far in the air, and with my fence, I was never going to use the full travel of the original. This is one is about 2/3 the travel, and a bit narrower. The distance between the channels is 5", which makes it easy to build a mounting jig/sled. Different take on the wingnuts included.

Please ignore the blue/grey gunk on the board, just some bits of over zealous blue tape from the print bed.

title: Delta Effector with Autolevel and fan shrouds

description.text:
UPDATE: Older Kossels have carriage rod spacing of 40mm, while the newer ones with this shroud have 42, I have added a version of the shroud with 40mm spacing to cover both older models and newer.

UPDATE: Added an improved version of the shroud to include exhaust vents for the cooling fan. Design that comes with New kossel's do not have this feature

UPDATE: After printing one out and double checking the measurements I noticed that for some reason I had the spacing for the rod mounts at 38mm which is incorrect, it has now been corrected to 42mm and the correct piece is available for download

OK So I recently purchased an upgraded Kossel Mini from China, the ones with the new effector that have the fan shrouds built in and the autolevel ability via the hotend. Another neat feature about the effector was it gives you an additional 20mm print height on the kossel minis. Long Story short I spend an evening reverse engineering it and here is the result. In the thing files you should find all 4 components which you can use to print your own upgraded effector for your kossel mini. It will require extra hardware such as an endstop, spring, and some extra nuts and bolts. Once I have one printed out and assembled I will add pic's of it. Let me know how it works for you
See my short video on the design in 123d Design on youtube at

https://youtu.be/NKfxJEzcwII

title: STUDY OF SOLIDS
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These objects have been designed and printed by students aged 14-15 of the secondary school "A. BERENINI" - FIDENZA (near Parma).
The activity has been carried out within the Erasmus+ Project PRINT STEM (www.printstemproject.eu).

Erasmus Print Stem.
Intellectual Output N.4: Study of solids.
Erasmus K2 “Print Stem” (using of 3D printer applied in scientific subjects) has been proposed as a new strategy to get students more interested in learning scientific subjects.
The main purpose of this project was:
1)Help students achieve new skills and acquire a multinational dimension of learning through international cooperation
2)Use e-learning to improve language abilities
3)Create flexible learning strategies
4)Improve the learning of unmotivated students at risk of abandoning school and the low-skilled ones
5)Enhance teachers’ proficiency

Object
The project consists of an inclined plane made of two different divergent and inclined guides and of solids: double cone, cylinder, sphere and pseudo sphere.
We tried to explain the mechanic paradox (a double cone which “ goes back to the top” of the inclined plane ) and observe the movement of other rotation solids. The class was split into five groups of four students each, and they had to project and print a complete kit having different dimensions.

title: Thinkpad 90W power supply window sill shelf

description.text: Ever have one of those inventions that you just know is going to make you rich? Yeah, this isn't one of them, but it does satisfy a (really specific) need. I leave a 90W power supply for my Thinkpad T530 at my designated spot on the couch, but it kept falling off and making dings on the window sill behind it. So I came up with this solution, I designed and 3D printed a little holder that fastens to the window sill with command strips. It's just the right size for the 90W power supply with walls to keep it from falling off and the front corners are rounded so it wouldn't hurt anything that bumped into it.

M2

Yes

doesn't matter

I used 20%

Notes:

Because I added the bottom lip, when printed upright this object requires a large area of support. Such a large area can cause bed adhesion issues (guess how I know), so I ended up printing this with a raft and support. Took longer and required some cleanup afterwards, but it came out perfect.

title: Heart Ocarina
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: An ocarina in the shape of a heart. After many iterations the relative tuning is precise. The small version in C plays a perfect C major tune. The larger version in G should be tuned in G major, but I haven't tested it yet. In any case the relative tuning is fine and it plays a precise major tune. I will post an update once I have tested it. The distance between finger holes of the small C version are pretty small. I can still play it but it is rather adapted to children's hands. The G version is for adults. The fingering is to open one hole after the other first of the right hand from the bottom to the top, then of the left hand from bottom to top, then the right thumb followed by the left thumb.

title: Pololu Zumo Reflectance Sensor Array Armor
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
After battling my Pololu Zumo robots for a while, one of them was blinded when it rode up the front of the other and scraped a surface mount capacitor off on the top of the plow. I decided it was time to put some basic armor on my robots so I printed an Arduino Uno plate to cover the top and designed this skid plate to protect the Reflectance Sensor Array.

There are no clips to hold it on but if your print is just right it should be a snug enough fit to hold itself on. Keep in mind that the cut of the PCB and the wiggle room of the soldered components and headers will vary a bit so you may need to tweak the SCAD file or file your print.

author: jlc53

description.text:
Use this thing to test te maximum torque of your motor. It's designed for a motor with a shaft with a min. diameter of 4.5mm and a max. diameter of 5.0mm. This is the right size for a Nema 17 motor.  
The radius of the wheel is about 3cm. I made holes in the object to make it easy to connect a piece of string.  
If you don't like the size of the hole or the size of the wheel, you can edit it by using the scad file, but i didn't put any vars or comments in it, but that won't be a problem if you understand the open scad language.

• Print the object.
  • Attach a piece of string.
  • Attach object to your motor.

  • Attach as much weight to the robe as your motor can handle.

  • Calculate Torque:
    maximum torque = Mass(kilogram) 9.81(meter/second^2) Radius(meter)
    or
    maximum torque = Force(Newton) * Radius(meter)
    • example:
    -Radius : 0.030 meter
    -Mass : You are lifting 0.780 kilogram
    Your maximum Torque = 0.780 9.81 0.030 = 0.23 NM(which is the same as 23 Ncm)

title: XLNC 1 - Xtra Large CNC Machine - Mill/3DPrint/Laser etch w/Custom GUI

description.text:
REV 2 is being released at the link bellow

You can still build REV 1 if you want. REV 2 and 1 share the same XY gantry and Bed parts, but different Z-axis parts. On Rev 1, the bed moves. On Rev 2, the bed is stationary while the Gantry goes up/down. This change was made due to planned implementation of tool changing.
LINK TO REV 2:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2757069

REV 1 DETAILS

This is a project I started a few months ago in an attempt to make a low cost, very large multipurpose CNC machine for my other "Projects".

Download the zip files attached to this project page: they contain the STL models.

  • For 25mm OD pipes: Download "25mm_OD.zip"
  • For 38.3mm OD pipes (default configuration used in the videos): Download "38_3mm_OD.zip"

Future tool attachments will be added, including the firmware configuration used on the RADDS board.

Basic final specs as pictured.

  • Machine footprint: 5'-5'-2.2'(L-W-H) (You can simply use shorter tubing to make a smaller, much more rigid machine)
  • Very large Build Volume when 3D printing: 2.69'-3.48'-1.06'(L-W-H)
  • Very large Area when Milling: 2.69'-3.48'- Tool length (~4" +)
  • Motion: 1.5" (38.3mm) OD. Electrical conduit with User adjustable roller bearings (use better/stiffer tubing if you can get your hands on them).
  • Use metal tubing with smoother surface and thicker walls if you want to expand your machine cutting/ printing area past the specs above.
  • Configurations for 25mm OD and 38.3mm OD pipes have been added.
  • Intended materials supported: Cutting medium to soft grade aluminum and other softer materials
  • Intended usage CNC milling, Laser etching/cutting. 3D printing multiple objects simultaneously

Design Features:

  • Table on Z axis: The Table goes up and down on this design.
  • Steel re-enforced GT2 belts: I cheaped out and got 6mm wide belts, but luckily purchased pulleys compatible with 10mm wide belts for future upgraded of belts if needed.
  • Stackable: Many of these machines can be stacked on top of one another
  • Support for toolset expansion: The gantry is made to support Wood routers, Dremels, heavy spindles, 3D printing filament Extruders (1 and up using mounting brackets), and is intended to support future robotic arm addition for hybrid 3D printing and finish milling operations.
  • Enclosure friendly: Since all movements are constrained within the machine's footprint, a full enclosure can be made for it.
  • Stiffer XY gantry: Future tests will be performed to get some actual numbers as to how accurately this particular design can cut hard materials. Since 3D printed parts are not well suited for FEA simulations, do not expect such testing to occur.
  • Adjustable Belt and Bearings: Belt tension is achieve using off the shelf products you can source at your local hardware store.

Update 11/6/16: Added Top and Bottom chassis block 3D models including motor mounts. XY carriage is being modified to be stiffer.

Update 11/11/16: Added X carriage 3D models including motor mounts. Y carriage is being modified to use similar parts.

Update 11/14/16: Updated X and Y carriage 3D models including motor and belt mounts.

Update 11/26/16: All 3D STL files scheduled for uploading on 11/27/16: Major changes were made to simplify parts of the machine and make them easier to 3D print. The current motion controller will be RADDS and CNC shield (running in mirror mode for X and Z axes) using DRV8825 Drivers and Repetier firmware and Host. Design to be promoted to Beta thereafter.

Update 12/07/16: Design is finalized and parts are being uploaded:

  • Old 3D models deleted
  • Old images deleted
  • New images uploaded (haha I kinda went overboard doing this in my kitchen).
  • Y & X carriage 3D Models included in zip file
  • Remaining 3D Models will be converted to STL, added to the zip file and uploaded daily (kinda very busy atm)
  • Test video uploaded (playing around with how fast I could push the DRV8825 Drivers before stalling the motors).
  • Video youtube link - https://youtu.be/bsenXD5oCrA
  • Final dimensions for my size machine updated.

Update 12/14/16: 3D STL file upload completed

  • Please re-download the attached zip file for the latest 3D STL models for this machine.
  • Added images of Makita RT0701C router mount.
  • Next tasks..Add a BOM

Update 1/7/17: - Currently testing Gcode compatibility with Repetier Firmware

  • Added images of X-axis pulley supports
  • Changed bed material from wood to more rigid yet still cheap wall mounting plastic (Fastrack)
  • Added STL files for bed clamp sockets (use together with thing 21057)
  • Added STL models for new 20x20mm to Bed (couplers)
  • Modified GRBL Post-Processor from Vectric to work with Repetier Firmware.
  • Successfully Tested Milling tool-chain compatibility (Vectric Aspire [CAD / CAM] --> Repetier Host with CNC extension [CNC GUI] --> Repetier Firmware [0.92] -->RADDS+CNC SHIELDS [Hardware]
  • Added images of initial movement and test cuts
  • Added video of initial test cuts just to test G-code compatibility: https://youtu.be/40uC6aKao1k

Update 1/19/17: - Currently test cutting materials
-Added video of cutting Wood fixture for aluminum stock: https://youtu.be/x6bRLzgBqbA

Update 02/02/17: - Currently test cutting materials

  • Added video of first very conservative cutting of aluminum stock: https://youtu.be/W4KUQvgwvOk
  • Added images of first prototype dust boot

Update 02/05/17: - Currently test cutting materials

  • Added video of second test cutting of aluminum stock: https://youtu.be/b2CTbTamWYk
  • Uploaded STL files for 25mm OD and 38.3mm OD pipe configurations.

Update 02/07/17: - Major update done to 25 mm design files

  • Updated effective pipe OD from 32mm to 25mm OD
  • Modified belt anchors to keep timing belts parallel along axis.

Update 03/12/17: - Eye can finally see without glasses!!! now onto More testing.

  • Finished testing Vectric Aspire Post for Repetier firmware (CNC mode only)
  • Testing HSMWorks (might work with Fusion360 too) Repetier compatible post-processor
  • Started sub-assembly SolidWorks assembly instructions.

Update 03/18/17: - Work on XLNC is temporarely halted while I upgrade my Flashforge Creator printers. Link to upgraded parts thing here:

  • http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2185486

Update 05/7/17: - ALPHA HSMWorks to Repetier/Marlin post-processor uploaded. File name: HSMWorks 3 Axis Repetier_Rev5.CPS

Update 06/15/17: - Marking HSMWorks to Repetier/Marlin post-processor as BETA.

Update 06/15/17: - Developing custom XLNC control panel plugin for Repetier Host 2.0: Current feature list to implement is:

  • User-selectable machine Mode (CNC, 3D PRINTER, LASER)
  • Remember last Work origin
  • User defined workspaces
  • Return to selected Origin
  • Users can edit and assign different GCODE or scripts to buttons
  • Still deciding on data handling structure since I won't use the registry.

Update 08/17/17: - Developing custom XLNC control panel plugin for Repetier Host 2.0: Current features implemented include:

  • User-selectable machine Mode (CNC, 3D PRINTER, LASER)
  • Return to selected Origin
  • Using SQLite Database (for coordinates) back-end and text files (to store User Gcode) for persistent storage.

Update 12/14/17: - Developing custom XLNC control panel plugin for Repetier Host 2.0: Current status:

  • Developing event handling scheme.
  • Testing Gcode parsing scheme

Update 1/6/18: - Major rework done to machine frame components to optimize print time, strength, and reduce part count.

  • Optimized Frame corner brace design from 4 pieces to 1 piece
  • Optimized Z axis design such that the gantry moves up/down, instead of moving the table up/down. this is done to reduce moving mass and allow heavy objects to be placed on bed.
  • Bed is now stationary
  • Optimized most parts to no longer need washers
  • Changed motor mounting orientation for X/Y axes to reduce strain on belt pulleys.

Next steps:

  • Release Alpha version of XLNC control panel as a separate "Thing"
  • Release XLNC 2 as separate "Thing"
  • Add 1st set of assembly videos

Note: For 25mm OD configuration, please report any issues you find. I don't have the physical space to build and test that configuration.

Printer:

Flashforge Creator Pro - Simplify 3D Slicer

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

300 um (0.3 mm)

Infill:

5% or more, 4 wall loops (or 1.6mm or more wall, Top, Bottom thickness)

Notes:

Due to the nature of the machine's design and anticipated usage (Milling metal accurately and very large 3D printing area), parts are designed to make the chassis very stiff.

All parts can be printed without supports and will fit standard 5 in x 5 in or bigger print beds.
TIPS:

  • Use a cooling fan when printing PLA
  • Use a better material such as PETG for even stronger parts (although this is more expensive)

Tip For stronger parts:

  • Before assembling the machine, coat the corner braces that hold your frame together using Smooth-On 3D Epoxy filler.
  • Print parts so that the largest face of each model sits on the print-bed

https://www.smooth-on.com/product-line/xtc-3d/

1-2 coats per part is enough. let dry for at least 24hrs before assembling the machine, otherwise those parts may crack during assembly.

comments.author: multicd1

comments.text: Hi MultiCD1. The control board at this time is: 1 RADDS board + 2 CNC shield boards. your motor wiring configuration will dictate how many boards you need. If you want to get the same performance as that shown in the videos, you need to control each motor with its own stepper driver IC in order to maximize torque. I do NOT recommend connecting motors in parallel or series (this will reduce your available torque and reduce maximum RPM, thereby slowing down the machine). The bed is moved by 4 individual NEMA17 motors (so you need 4 separate stepper drivers just for that, hence why i'm using CNC shield boards): the same control signal is then fed into all 4 channels on the CNC shield boards. The X AXIS is moved by 2 NEMA23 motors, the Y axis is moved by 1 big NEMA23 motor. I'm working on some bill of materials and documentation for this machine.
comments.author: multicd1

comments.text: There are additional parts you need to purchase. I am working on a BOM at this time and assembly manual. This machine only uses NEMA17 on Z axis. NEMA 23 for all other axes.

title: War Peace Order Force - My first Sense Scan

description.text:
Blog post:
http://toddblatt.blogspot.com/2013/11/first-sense-scan.html This morning I walked two blocks from my apartment over to the park by the Walter's Art Museum in Baltimore, in the shadow of the Washington Monument. There are many large statues in this area, and for smaller ones, one at each 'corner' of the circle that goes around the monument. Metal letters spelling out the words "War, Peace, Order and Force" are below each. I brought the Sense and my laptop out to scan one of them. Here's the result of my first scan. In the Sense scanning software, you have options right when you open the software. It asks you if you're scanning a person or an object, and then it asks you how big the object is... small medium or large. I scanned the War sculpture and the next scan using the object and large settings. I think I made a mistake and didn't have color on when I exported the file, and I loaded a new scan so all I've got are the exported .ply and .stl scans. When I opened the .ply in Meshlab, there was no color data, so I'm assuming I had a setting wrong when I exported. While scanning I know that color was on. Overall using the scanner feels a lot like the other PrimeSense scanners, but the software is really what sets it apart. It's simple and straightforward, no need to jump between software packages to go from scan data to printable object. When I scan with my Asus Xtion Pro, I needed to originally struggle with the ReconstructMe settings to get it to initialize, save using the command prompt, load the file into Meshmixer and clean up the scan there manually. I like doing it manually with meshmixer, and don't mind the command prompt, but the average consumer wouldn't use a device where all those steps are needed. Doing it with the Sense software was a breeze. Of course, that's why this costs $399 and not ~$150 like the others. The software is certainly the biggest added value to this scanner over the Kinect or Asus. I bumped in to Yair at Dooby's (where I'm currently typing this up) and did a quick 15 second scan. I got it right this time and was able to export the color data. I didn't go back and tell it that I was scanning a smaller thing, nor did I switch the setting to 'person.' Sorry Yair, now 3d systems thinks you're an object and not a person. I liked the feedback it gave me while I was scanning, though it was frustrating at times. It helps guide you to make sure the scanner is the right distance away from the object. It suggests 15". While I was scanning the War sculpture, It would sometimes switch from "Too Close" to "Too Far" as I passed by parts of the sculpture which protruded more, like the horse's head. I did find that it would keep scanning even if it was telling you that you were too close or two far. Being too close made the scan go very slowly, and being too far would sometimes make you lose tracking. It does a nice overlay to help guide you to line up the scan with the sculpture if you lose tracking, and usually can find itself and resume. Overall this is a great device and excellent software execution by 3D Systems

comments.text: Great scan, may I ask how long it took?
comments.author: Apofus67

comments.text:

author: vaigyanik

title: Hermione Granger's Wand Resliced, with battery holder- Harry Potter

description.text:
Made a new battery holder for the Hermione Wand by Fritz Laun (http://www.thingiverse.com/fflbm4/about).

It holds the two batteries listed in the original thing (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1089917) and uses a faucet spring (https://smile.amazon.com/KISSLER-RP4993-Delta-Faucet-Spring/dp/B00B483CV6/ref=sr_1_11?ie=UTF8&qid=1477623694&sr=8-11&keywords=faucet+spring) to hold the batteries steady.

Soldering to the spring didn't work well, so I soldered the wire to itself and crimped it to the spring flat.

The battery holder slips into the wand through the switch hole, so you can disassemble and replace the batteries when needed.

Additionally, I resliced the wand so that the top and bottom aren't aligned - that way there's a nice big overlap for gluing. I held mine together with super glue, which worked wonders on the clear PETG as well as some woodfill.

To install, wire up the LED first. The wires should reach from the installed LED to the end of the wand. It's also really helpful to know which wire is positive - i.e. attached to the long leg of the LED.

Next, glue everything together. Route the wires out the switch hole. I used binder clips to hold the pieces in place, and the heated bed on my printer to make the glue dry faster.

Wire up the positive LED wire to the power switch.
Wire the negative LED through the battery holder side with a single hole, and attach to the spring. I soldered it to itself, then wedged it into the spring.

Use a new jump wire to run through the battery holders other side, with two holes. The wire should go in one hole, out the other, and get soldered to itself - so you'll need to strip about a half an inch.

The other end of that wire goes to the non-pupulated leg of the power switch.

Put the batteries in, and test!

Finally, carefully slide the battery holder into the wand, then all the wires, and finally the power switch. I bent the switch legs a good bit, although I'm not sure it was necessary.

description.text:
These speakers are a customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:451253, created using customizer, http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=451253. All credit goes to Rich Olson who built this - http://www.nothinglabs.com/speakergen-parametric-3d-printed-speaker-enclosures/

It was printed on the Monoprice Select Mini using Hatchbox Wood filament at 215 extruder/55 bed temperature. I used a raft but no supports. The mini was able to handle printing the roof of the box without them, so ymmv on that.

I ordered the drivers and terminals from parts-express.
Drivers - https://www.parts-express.com/dayton-audio-rs75-4-3-reference-full-range-driver-4-ohm--295-380

Terminal - https://www.parts-express.com/round-speaker-terminal-cup-2-15-16-gold-banana-binding-post--260-283

Using the Lepai 2020+ mini amp with a 12V 3A power supply - https://www.amazon.com/Lepai-LP-2020A-Tripath-Amplifier-included/dp/B009IJTMOE/

I wasn't expecting the best sound quality, but was very surprised how good they sounded. I finished them using two coats of minwax stain and two coats of polyurethane.

Using the following options:

speakerHoleDiameter = 57
manualBoxVolume = .58
driverFS = 73
speakerScrewHoleSpacing = 64
portLocation = back
driverVas = 1.132
enableClosedBoxCalc = no
boxThickness = 11
portYOffset = 0
terminalScrewHoleSpacing = 61
portXOffset = 0
numberOfSpeakerScrewHoles = 4
speakerScrewHoleDiameter = 3.25
numberOfTerminalScrewHoles = 4
driverQts = 0.68
portWallThickness = 5
portLength = 100
terminalHoleDiameter = 50
portInternalDiameter = 20
boxDepthRatio = .8
makePort = no
boxWidthRatio = .95
terminalScrewHoleDiameter = 3.2
terminalType = terminal cutout
wireDiameter = 2.2
boxHeightRatio = 1.1
boxQ = 0.9
showSpecs = no

I created this filament spool holder because for the printable ones where the spool sits on top of the wheels, my spools kept falling over because of the jerking of the extruder.

This one requires:

  • 1x 8mm x 10cm rod as an axle
  • 2x 8mm bearings (e.g. 608 bearing)

Printable on a standard 20cm x 20cm bed.

For best use, this may also need some axle adapters / rod collars for difference sizes of spools. I have designed these also and will post a shareable one soon.

title: Educational Model for Thoracic Epidural Procedure

description.text:
Thoracic epidurals are used for analgesia in many chest and abdominal surgeries. Their use has been shown to improve surgical outcomes. Residents often struggle in their first attempts at thoracic epidurals. Learning the anatomy, visualizing the geometry of the needle approach, and developing a feel for the relevant tissues can prove challenging. We developed an inexpensive educational model for thoracic epidurals using 3D-printing and other DIY tools. In the manual, we provide step-by-step instructions on fabrication and assembly of this model.

Please let us know what you think in the comments!

description.text:
This is a case for the XBee Interface Board (XBIB). It should work with the version that has the two sets of LEDs, barrel connector for power, and USB Type B port on one side (XBIB-U-DEV, XBIB-U-SS). There are five total standoffs beneath the board supporting it with three of them having pegs that will slide into the mounting holes in the board. Friction alone seems to do a decent job of keeping it in place.

No top is included as part of the case and the bottom is open to speed printing and reduce material. I've attached the scad file in case you want to customize it with OpenSCAD. I've paramaterized some things like the wall thickness and heights for standoffs.

The walls of the attached sql are 1.6 mm so if you have a 0.4mm nozzle you will probably want to print with four layers for the best outcome. As is it will probably only work if your XBee has a chip, whip or U.FL antenna. XBees with an RPSMA will probably collide with the case. I don't have any surface mount XBees handy so I wasn't able to check if they overhang (if they do they won't fit the case).

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I printed with both PLA and PETG with no supports. Depending on how well your printer is at bridging you might have some problems bridging the cutouts for the power jack and usb port without some sagging (mine handled PLA perfectly, PETG needing some light sanding). The attached stl has 1.6mm walls so I went with (0.8mm) since I have a 0.4mm nozzle and wanted to avoid infill on them. The wall thickness if customizable in the scad file so you can tweak it to your liking.

With the above settings the rigidity and strength of the PLA versions was pretty nice. The PETG version was a stronger but I didn't like the feel quite as much.

description.text: just playing around

print_settings.Notes:: The entire print is ABS. The sprockets and belt links were printed in fine resolution. The rest was printed in fast mode.

description.text: This is a custom design for a modular plastic conveyor belt. I started by designing the belt links and sprockets. I went on to design and print the majority of a working conveyor belt that can run via a dc motor or a stepper motor (as shown). It also accepts a Koyo Encoder for tracking motion. After some adjustments it runs smoothly and without problems. Please see the "LEGO converyor" for more details...

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The entire print is ABS. The sprockets and belt links were printed in fine resolution. The rest was printed in fast mode.

All of the plastic connects to two 1" 8020 aluminum extrusions. Mine were 10" in length. I used pieces of extra filament to connect the links together. I had to clean out some of the holes with a drill bit. The pieces that attach to the 8020 use the standard 1/4" hardware. The stepper motor, encoder etc use m3 screws (8mm mostly, 1" length for encoder -- didn't test that yet). I used 1/4" d shafts from robotshop. The bearings and other parts came from there too. I can provide more detail on parts if people are interested.

This is used to draw circles while maintaining a slim form factor. It was designed to fit into a pencil pouch or pencil holder.  It is simple and works with almost any pencil making it easy to use.  To operate all you have to do is use one finger to hold the pivot tip on the paper, insert your pencil into the desired circle radius and draw away!

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/eVQTECrITbL

This is a leg prototype.
Nothing attached for servo control yet.
But ideas should be available for me and others to build from.

title: VeryGrind
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Why spend $100 on this jig? Print one yourself! If you have to ask what this is, then it probably isn't for you. But I'll be nice, it's a jig to put a fingernail grind on a bowl gouge. Please, those who do know, do not laugh at my horrible gouge, that's what 6 months of free hand sharpening a gouge will do to it. Hence, why I made this thing.

I'd have a pic of it in use, but I'm still building the rest of the sharpening jig.

Based upon Marius Hornberger's video on his (wooden) shop built jig (https://youtu.be/sfmIv0iXjis). I made some minor changes, based on the medium used, but the parts are directly copied from his plans. I'm using a washer held in place by a nut, in the "wrong" order, to hold the gouge in place. Works fine for my 3/8"(?) gouge, but a larger gouge may require something like a threaded washer, as the nut takes up too much space.

Print the arm with solid infill. I printed mine at 25%, and it's a bit flimsy. Usable, but I'd rather have a more solid arm. And since, ya know, if you need this jig, you probably have access to a bandsaw, so I'd recommend making the arm out of 1/4" ply. If you do, just note the holes are space exactly 2" apart on mine. The original (included pdf) was a bit different.

How to use video: https://youtu.be/j__h45sQErg

(Note: in assembled.stl, the nut is shown on the top of the block, it actually goes on the bottom. The topassembly.stl file corrects this. The assembled file was just a mock up to make sure everything lined )

IF YOU ARE HAVING ISSUES WITH SIZING: The M6 knob is metric, but every other file is in imperial, Inches. The M6 Knob is from a different project, and it's close enough to use for a 1/4" bolt, so I didn't think it would be needed to change the units. IMPORT ALL THE OTHER FILES IN IMPERIAL.

Print: 1 arm, 1 top assembly, 2 adjusters and 3 knobs. I used the "quarterinchthick" knob in the photo, but they are too big for the jig to lay completely flat, I included some of my 6mm knobs, which should work. The "qit" knob works great on the top though.

After printing, use 1/4" bolts (6mm should work fine too) to assemble the Adjusters and the Arm. The center axle should use a nylon lock nut, tighten it snug, but the arm has to slide. Use two knobs on the other bolt to make the arm adjustable. (Use the Assembled.stl for guidance)

Drop a hex nut into the opening of the top assembly, glue in place. Make sure the nut is square to the top and bottom faces by pulling down on it with a bolt as you glue.

Make sure the top edges of the adjusters and flush and even, tighten down the arm bolts, making sure the arm is out of the way. Using a good glue (Abs glue, Epoxy, CA might work too), glue the adjusters into the 4 slots on the upper assembly. Clamp gently if necessary.

Place the third knob on a bolt, thread through the glued nut. Place a nut on the bolt as it emerges, and place a washer after that, with the tip of the bolt ending up a bit proud of the washer. This T shape will sit in and on the the flute of the gouge. Yes, it's a pain trying to not lose the washer, but I didn't have any better hardware available.

Print off a copy of the requisite 2" adjusting block (not included. It's a block with a 2" hole in it, CAD 101 stuff), or drill one in a block of wood. Watch the video for proper use of the jig.

title: No Support Kobold D-Ring and Belt Hook

description.text:
This is superficially accurate Kobold D-ring for ESB Luke or ROTJ Vader lightsabers. I designed it to not require supports and mount better to a flat surface, unlike the real Kobold design which has a curved mounting surface and unsupported top edges.

I cut about 4.25mm out of the ends of the D-ring to give it the correct look, then paused the print about .4mm from the end of the D-ring hole, snapped the ring in place, then finished the print. Flexing the D-ring to fit into the hole after printing might work too, but this seemed easier to me. A printed D-ring would be much easier to slip on after, but I'd be worried about it being strong enough to not break or pull free.

I also made a hanger. If you want it really wide with the hook in the middle, I also made a "hanger edge" that doesn't have a hook. After using it for a while, I realized that the lightsaber needs to hang on the left side, where my belt has the trailing edge (this is for Halloween, not 501st, so I'm not making a new belt). I've therefore uploaded a new double gap hanger. While I was doing that I also made a double gap hanger with 3mm bolt hole and a side piece with same. I don't know how much that will wreck the strength of the hanger. If it breaks on you, let me know and I'll make a stronger one.

Printer:

Folger Tech Kossel revB

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

It's not that big. 4 perimeters is basically solid.

Notes:

With Simplify3D I printed the first part to 4.6mm, snapped in the ring, then finished the print. Your settings may work better with a different number. Basically I did it at the point where there were only 2 more 0.2mm layers to print, then the top. This kept my nozzle from colliding with the ring, but I also have more than a 0.5mm hop on my prints. Without that hop the first layer would probably strike the ring. It took some force to snap it into the groove, but not so much that it damaged the print.

The hanger prints on its side so each layer is the same as every other.

1. Find a schematic of questionable value.

Using a schematic that I have no specific knowledge of the accuracy I did a model that would hold a 3mm diameter D-ring (1-1/8 inch Zinc Plated) from a home improvement store.

The schematic is - I believe - from someone going by the name "Darth Saber" arrived at via therpf.com forum. I'm not trying to besmirch his honor by saying they are of questionable value; I just don't know how many of the numbers are extrapolations and guesses. So I'm taking them at face value because I'm certainly not finding better numbers anywhere else after hours of searching.

7mm channel in the top down view, 14mm outside edge, 30mm long, 6mm high.
Screw heads of 5mm.
D-Ring 3mm diameter (check) and overall length of 26 (off by only a 4 mm, so not bad).

2. Take the numbers you can and make up what you don't know.

Bottom layer of the mount is 2mm thick. Middle section is 3mm high to accommodate the 3mm ring. Top layer is 1mm thick (for a total of 6mm high). Cut a 3.1mm hole in the side (which means it grazes the top and bottom layers a little - I hadn't thought it through perfectly when I started).

Two screw holes are 8mm apart, center to center. First screw hole center is 6mm from the edge. It looked about right, so I went for it. The actual holes are 4mm in diameter, with a 5mm countersink cutout at the top. I beveled the edge from the 5mm cutout down to the 4mm one because I thought it would help the screws sit correctly. Mostly I thought it looked better.

3. Supports are for suckers. Or: Holding the lightsaber is better than dropping it on the ground.

The strongest way to print it is probably on the side (D-ring holes vertical) but that would need lost of support and would prevent printing the D-ring into position. Next best is on the back, but the normal clip would require supports all along the length to hold up the lip. Rather than go on to printing it on the front where it would require no supports but be weak on all holes, I just fudged it until version 2 worked.

Added a bevel from the floor to the rim to allow for a gradual supported overhang. It looks the same from the top as the correct version, but isn't. Bonus side effect: more plastic holding the top layers on the bottom layers, meaning less chance of the D-ring pulling the top off the clip.

4. Supports are still for suckers.

The only belt hanger I found involved supports - a large belt clip part, and a small round, centered hook.

I made a new one that is only 12mm wide so it fits inside the D-ring perfectly. Print it on its side, and it just prints the same layer over and over until it is done. If you want one that is thicker (16mm would still fit the D-ring admirably) just scale the Z. If you want one that is way thicker, print two hanger edges, one hanger, then glue them together so you have one hook in the center. It's designed for a 5mm thick and 36mm tall belt. Beveled inside edges to keep from damaging the belt and add a tiny bit of strength. Top and bottom edges are flat to allow for chaining and secure printing, so maybe file them down a little to round them off.

Erasmus Print Stem.

Erasmus K2 “Print Stem” (using of 3D printer applied in scientific subjects) has been proposed as a new strategy to get students more interested in learning scientific subjects.
The main purpose of this project was:
1)Help students achieve new skills and acquire a multinational dimension of learning through international cooperation;
2)Use e-learning to improve language abilities;
3)Create flexible learning strategies;
4)Improve the learning of unmotivated students at risk of abandoning school and the low-skilled ones;

If you add a surface (e.g. a lexan plate) to your 3d printer bed it will cause the Z axis to home incorrectly. For example a 2mm plate would cause the Z home position to be 2mm BELOW where it should be. This can make it impossible to adjust the bed level because the adjustment screws operate across a finite range.

To resolve this problem you need to reset the vertical Z home position by an equivalent distance. That can be done by physically adjusting the microswitch - or using this thing the microswitch can be fooled into resetting at a different height.

This thing provides several shims which slip onto the back riser of the Makerbot 2 which triggers the Z home microswitch. These shims may or may not work on other clone printers, it depends whether the clone offers a similar riser to trigger the Z home microswitch.

remixed_from.title: Wade L3K Extruder (prusa I3) compatible filament flexible By Skarab (JHead - Hexagon - E3DV6 - Aluhotend V7 et AllinOne Compatible)

title: Wade L3K Extruder V2 (prusa I3 & I3 like, itopie...) compatible filament flexible (E3D, AIO, Hexagon, Hexa AO ...)

description.text:
Le L3K V2 est enfin là

Mis à jour le 02/11/2016 Voir ci-dessous paragraphe "Update"

Work in progress -- il peut y avoir des modifications apportées suivant les retours utilisateurs

La V2 est actuellement en phase de test publique, je n'ai pas assez de cas différents pour le tester moi même, donc si vous pouvez me faire des retours en particuliers sur les hotends E3D & chinoises car je ne les ai pas testé.

Compatible uniquement en filament 1.75mm pour l'instant.

Les principales nouveautés :

  • Réduction de la taille de la biggear GT2 pour pouvoir tendre à souhait la courroie
  • Trous oblongs incurvés pour la fixation moteur pour tendre facilement la courroie
  • Passage aux fanducts avec des ventilateurs radiaux (gain flux d'air, gain de 1-2cm en X)
  • Fixation de l'ensemble des fanducts par l'avant
  • Possibilité de réglage en hauteur des fanducts d'impression sur environ 2-3cm pour être compatible avec toutes les hotends
  • Flange de maintient de la hotend en face avant pour une maintenance aisée
  • Fixation des fanducts d'impressions au flange, ce qui permet de tout retirer en enlevant le flange, libère l'espace en maintenance
  • Verrouillage du idler avec une pièce supplémentaire de blocage, pour une ouverture/fermeture facilitée (à tester à l'usage pour la force de maintient que j'ai fait légère pour permettre de bien compresser les ressorts malgrès tout sans compliquer l'ouverture)
  • Entrée conique pour insérer le filament facilement
  • Le body a été intégralement redessiné sous inventor, les empreintes à écrou on été revu pour un ajustement au poil, surtout pour le flange ou ils sortaient trop facilement au démontage

L3K V1 Compatible :

  • Le idler est censé être compatible avec le L3K V1 si vous souhaitez juste le blocage express (vous printez les 2 STL nécessaires)

Pour la partie gear d'entrainement, le L3K V2 est d'origine en GT2.
Ceci dit, on peut y mettre les gears classique ou herringbone du L3K V1 (la biggear GT2 a été modifié donc il vaut mieu la réimprimer elle est mieu la nouvelle).

Ce projet est issu du Wade L3K V1 qui avait été réalisé par Skarab & moi même.

Parts list
  • Hobbed bolt : http://ebay.eu/2dOdkaJ
  • 1pc courroie GT2 - Pour l'entrainement de la biggear : http://bit.ly/L3K_GT2
  • 2pcs Ventilateurs blower 50x15mm : http://bit.ly/L3K_RADIAL
  • 1pc Poulie GT2 16 dents axe de 5mm - Pour l'entrainement de la GT2 par le moteur
  • 2pcs M3 CHC 50mm - Pour ressort du idler
  • 2pcs Ecrou M8 - Pour hobbed bolt
  • 1pc Axe M8x20mm - Pour le roulement 608 du idler
  • 3pcs Roulements 608 - Pour hobbed bolt et idler
  • 2pcs Ressorts 6*6mm - Pour les ressorts du idler
  • 1pc Ventilateur 40x40x10mm ou 30x30mm suivant hotend, voir ci-dessous - Pour refroidir la coldend de la hotend
  • De la visserie m3 (10, 12, 14, 16, 20mm) pour différentes parties de l'extrudeur
Hotends detail

Hexagon, AIO, S1, JHead, Aluhotend:

  • Fanduct 40mm Hexagon_AIO_S1_JHead.stl

Hexagon AO :

  • Fanduct 30mm Hexagon AO.stl

E3D & E3D (jhead) Chinoise (à confirmer) :

  • Fanduct 40mm E3D & Chinoise.stl
  • Adaptateur_E3D_Body.stl
Post printing

Body :

  • Enlever le support dans le logement du roulement 608 coté biggear
  • Enlever le support de fixation du Idler
  • Si possible passer un coup de perçeuse avec foret 2mm dans le passage du filament

Fanduct Blower :

  • Enlever le support au milieu du logement du ventilateur
Advice & Tips

Montage :

  • Monter l'ensemble Flange + ventilation d'impression sur le body avec la hotend en place puis visser le fanduct coldend en dernier.

Utilisation :

  • Vitesse des ventilateurs radiaux conseillé : 70% (Au delà, trop d'air généré qui perturbe la hotend)
  • Distance de rétraction conseillée : 1mm environ
  • Vitesse de rétractation : entre 20 & 40mm/s
Coming Soon
  • Support de BLTouch
  • Support de bande à led
Update (Work in Progress)

Mise à jour du 02/11/2016 : Eloignement de 6mm du body par rapport au X carriage car les "itopie" avait la fixation du moteur qui tapait le cadre vertical en haut.

description.text:
Another cookie cutter; this time it's from a drawing a working colleague made.

It's supposed to look like a witch and there'll be two further cutters in the next days that belong to the witch-cutter: Hänsel & Gretel.
Ok, this went faster than intented: here they are. They both have some kind of suitcase... dunno why. Probably they're annoyed by the witches neverending attempts to seduce them so they packed their belongings and are about to move away or something. Perhaps the witch was successful and they move into the witches house? I gotta ask my colleague about that one some day.

Haven't printed it out yet but it looks fine in the slicer so I don't expect any surprises. Will update a photo of the final cutter in the evening.

Walls are thick enough for a single-wall print with a 0,6mm nozzle.

Notes:

I'll print it in PET-G again and recommend everyone else to do the same. Awesome material for such things.
LCD 16x2 support for protoboard

title: Waco UPF-7 Biplane simplified cnc/laser
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
It came to my mind, that I had created quite some simplified plane models by now, but not one biplane. The construction needed to be a little more complex, but it's definitely worth it.

My build was done on a desktop cnc-machine by Stepcraft from 6.5 mm beech plywood using a spiral-toothed 1.2 mm flute. Glued together and nicely sanded it's a great toy for boys (of different age).
A laser cutter might be a good alternative tool to create smaller versions.

Visit https://www.zenziwerken.de/en/Spielsachen/Flugzeugmodelle for more designs.

Consider a small donation (1$) if you like this design. Any amount will help me keeping up with my work.

Keep in mind, that the stl-file is just for validating the construction and viewing in the browser.

I searched 3-view drawings of this plane to create the outlines. I traced the images in Illustrator and carved out the main features. The slots were a result of trail and error. Before building the plane I did a 3D validation in SketchUp. Then I nested the parts as close as possible for production on a cnc-router.

description.text:
It's always a pain to find a good costume for halloween when you wear glasses. Clark Kent do but not Superman, neither Wolverine. Darth Vador is not supposed to have eye problem and if he has, his helmet would fix it and it doesn't have enough space inside for additional Earth made glasses. etc etc etc.
The idea is to use my glasses as part of the costume, and more precisely as a support for the main costume accessory. With eye ro8ot, I don't need any supersuit, or any other extra show off stuff. It's all in the eye !

Notes:

no support needed if printed upside down.
add a led a switch and a battery
the shape suits specifically my own glasses. I will need to be reworked for any other glasses.

comments.text: With your beard, you look like you could easily go as Dr. Gordon Freeman, from Half-Life.

thanks !
you're right : one of the most difficult part is to design a model specifically adjusted to one's glasses. The other one is to find room between the lens and the eye to place a switch, a led and a battery. Fortunately 3D printing allows you to make a very unique model that fits all your unique specifications !
have fun making it !

description.text: Based on R-Design's design, these are print in place hinges for the BigBox. Both base panel and side panel hinges are provided.

Printer:

Bigbox

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

12%

Notes:

The design is created with 0.25 layers in mind in order to create the right slice for the hinge pinion rotate freely after printing. No supports are required; the parts provide support for each other.

print_settings.Notes:: Printed in PLA and I used the inverted stl file to avoid the need for supports

description.text:
These spark plugs were originally for a model rotary Wankel engine. The source file is in OpenScad and included so you can alter sizes to suit your project. The code will print between one or more spark plugs in one go.

I suggest printing at least three plugs at a time to allow the narrow parts to cool between layers. A raft reduces problems with adhesion to the print bed due to the narrow base but otherwise settings are not critical.

Included is are stl files which print the plugs print upside down to avoid the need for support.

Printer:

Kossel Mini from think3dprint3d

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Layer 0.3mm thick 0.66mm wide

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Printed in PLA and I used the inverted stl file to avoid the need for supports

HT Connector

To complete the model there is a hole in the top of the insulator suitable for a 8mm long 2.5mm dia machine screw.

OpenSCAD

Being familiar with programming code I just followed the cheat sheet in the OpenScad documentation.
